clinical_study.brief_title: Reducing 30-day Readmissions in Patients With Heart Failure Through Pharmacist Discharge Medication Services
clinical_study.official_title: Reducing 30-day Readmissions in Patients With Heart Failure Through Pharmacist Discharge Medication Services

brief_summary.textblock: Patients admitted for heart failure that are provided discharge medication services by a pharmacist are less likely to be readmitted within 30 days of primary admission.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients readmitted to the hospital within 30 days of primary heart failure admission

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients who visit the emergency department within 30 days of primary heart failure admission
Number of medication discrepancies identified and the number of medication discrepancies resolved by the pharmacist at discharge.
Number of short term goals set by patient's at discharge and the number of short term goals met by patient's at the 7-10 follow up phone call.
secondary_outcome.description: Number of short term goals set will be compared to the number of goals patients achieved, comparison will be calculated by percentage

arm_group.description: Discharge medication services included: Discharge medication reconciliation Identification of medication discrepancies and resolution Medication counseling using health coaching techniques with short term goal setting and follow up phone call
Current standard of care provided by nursing staff.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of heart failure, discharged from any medical service
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unwilling to participate, discharged to nursing/rehab facility, non-English speaking, resident unavailable
